analysis_results.question_text: Does the company consider financial risks associated with rising compliance and testing costs for registration and re-registration?

answer.classification_justification: [REFINED ANALYSIS] SQM has provided quantified financial impacts related to environmental compliance and permitting costs. The company discloses accumulated disbursements in environmental projects, including those for verification and control of compliance with ordinances and laws, totaling MUS$ 47.025 as of December 31, 2023. Furthermore, a portion of "other environmental expenses" (35%) is specifically allocated to normalization, processing (tramitaciones), advisory services, and compliance with programs aimed at minimizing environmental impacts. Specific environmental permitting costs are also detailed in a table.

evidence.source_url: https://intel.tracker-group.org/org_library/FactSet/Filings/05HZV9-E/Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile SA (SQM-CL) - Annual Report for period end 31-Dec-2023 (Spanish) - PDF - 1 _ 4_20240228-61a61d1a-b2d6-ee11-abd8-12bc89a8f273_0_content.md
evidence.text: Los desembolsos acumulados en proyectos de inversiones asociados a materias ambientales en procesos productivos, verificación y control del cumplimiento de ordenanzas y leyes relativas a procesos e instalaciones industriales, en que ha incurrido la Sociedad y sus filiales, al 31 de diciembre de 2023 ascienden a MUS$ 47.025 y los principales gastos medioambientales son los siguientes: - Otros gastos ambientales 35%: Gastos asociados a la normalización, tramitaciones, asesorías y cumplimiento de los programas para que el desarrollo de sus actividades la minimización de los efectos sobre el entorno.

evidence.source_url: https://intel.tracker-group.org/org_library/FactSet/Filings/05HZV9-E/Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile SA (SQM-CL) - Annual Report for period end 31-Dec-2023 (Spanish) - PDF - 1 _ 4_20240228-61a61d1a-b2d6-ee11-abd8-12bc89a8f273_0_content.md
evidence.text: | SQM Salar S.A. | 19-S021500 - Mejoras SK-1300 2021 | El proyecto considera mejoras en prácticas y reportabilidad según norma internacional SK-1300 para mantener estándar frente a auditorías y dar cumplimiento anual a las exigencias de la SEC (Security Exchange Commission). | Tramitación Ambiental | Gasto | 1 | 9 | 17 | 31-12-2024 |

answer.summary: [REFINED ANALYSIS] SQM has provided quantified financial impacts related to environmental compliance and permitting costs. The company discloses accumulated disbursements in environmental projects, including those for verification and control of compliance with ordinances and laws, totaling MUS$ 47.025 as of December 31, 2023. Furthermore, a portion of "other environmental expenses" (35%) is specifically allocated to normalization, processing (tramitaciones), advisory services, and compliance with programs aimed at minimizing environmental impacts. Specific environmental permitting costs are also detailed in a table.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company consider financial risks of of increasing pesticide bans and restrictions reducing market access?

answer.classification_justification: The company's 2023 consolidated financial statements, particularly the "Contingencies and restrictions" note, do not contain any disclosure regarding financial risks stemming from increasing pesticide bans and restrictions impacting market access. The contingencies detailed in the document relate to various lawsuits and fines unrelated to this specific environmental regulatory risk.
answer.summary: The company's 2023 consolidated financial statements, particularly the "Contingencies and restrictions" note, do not contain any disclosure regarding financial risks stemming from increasing pesticide bans and restrictions impacting market access. analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose financial risks related to human health problems from its products? Please return NONE if there is no disclose at all, UNCLEAR if there is some mention of risk but no link to financial risk, PARTIAL if there is mention of financial risk, YES if there are numbers attached to financial risks related to human health problems.

answer.classification_justification: SQM acknowledges that health impacts, which include those related to their products (classified as hazardous to human health), could have a "significant negative impact on our revenue, profit and business." The company details product hazards, regulatory compliance efforts, and risk assessments related to health and safety impacts from its products. However, specific financial valuations or estimates of these risks are not provided.

evidence.text: It could have a significant negative impact on our revenue, profit and business if it affects the markets in which we operate, our customers or our suppliers.

One hundred percent of lithium products are consid ered hazardous chemical substances for human health and the environment, and belong to Categories 1 and 2 of the Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS).
Lithium carbonate is listed in California Proposal 65. No specific analysis related to this regula tion was conducted in 2023.

However, the Company does keep updated information on product hazards and risks. In this context, given the European officials’ proposal to classify lithium compounds as concerning, SQM has promoted an initiative with other global lithium producers to conduct a more exhaustive risk assess ment (Risk Management Option Assessment, RMOA) for the entire life cycle of four lithium compounds. This would also deliver the data necessary to safely handle our products, minimizing the impact on health and the environment.

It is worth mentioning that no cases of non-compliance with the regulations or voluntary codes related to lithium product impacts on health and safety were identified in 2023. There were no cases of non-compliance with the regulations or voluntary codes related to lithium product information and labeling.

When levels of impurities or inten tional ingredients exceed the limits based on the Glob ally Harmonized System, the products are classified as toxic to reproduction under category 1B and labeled as such to communicate the risk associated with these products.

No non-compliance with regulations or voluntary codes has been identified with regard to the impacts of prod ucts and services on health and safety. The following cases of regulatory non-compliance were identified in 2023 with regard to product informa tion and labeling: * Ultrasol 15-5-15 product, California (United States): The stated nutritional content did not align with the information contained on the label. It was identified as a typographic error that did not result in fines.

answer.summary: SQM acknowledges that health impacts, which include those related to their products (classified as hazardous to human health), could have a "significant negative impact on our revenue, profit and business." The company details product hazards, regulatory compliance efforts, and risk assessments related to health and safety impacts from its products. However, specific financial valuations or estimates of these risks are not provided.
answer.notes: D-Rag evidence count: 7. Human verified: False

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company consider financial risks related to waterway pollution and eutrophication from nutrient runoff when the company's products are applied by farmers? Do not consider factory sources of pollution.

answer.classification_justification: The provided documents from SQM (2022 financial statements) do not contain any disclosure regarding financial risks related to waterway pollution and eutrophication from nutrient runoff when the company's products are applied by farmers. While the documents mention general environmental management practices and compliance with environmental regulations, there is no specific acknowledgment or financial risk disclosure related to nutrient runoff, eutrophication, or waterway pollution from agricultural application of the company's products. The environmental sections focus on facility-level compliance and asset management rather than downstream product-use environmental risks.
answer.summary: The provided documents from SQM (2022 financial statements) do not contain any disclosure regarding financial risks related to waterway pollution and eutrophication from nutrient runoff when the company's products are applied by farmers. While the documents mention general environmental management practices and compliance with environmental regulations, there is no specific acknowledgment or financial risk disclosure related to nutrient runoff, eutrophication, or waterway pollution from agricultural application of the company's products. The environmental sections focus on facility-level compliance and asset management rather than downstream product-use environmental risks.
answer.notes: D-Rag evidence count: 0. Human verified: False

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company consider financial risks related to high energy production processes and N2O emissions from field application?

answer.classification_justification: The company explicitly discloses financial risks related to N2O emissions and energy production processes. It quantifies an internal carbon price of US$15 per ton of CO2 equivalent emissions (which includes N2O). Additionally, it states a current tax payment of ThUS$ 360 for emissions in 2023 and identifies a potential future financial risk if all emissions become subject to this tax. Furthermore, the company quantifies a potential "material loss" from purchasing excess electricity for its operations, directly addressing the financial risk of high energy production.

evidence.text: The gases included are: CO2, CH4, N2O. It is worth mentioning that our emissions are not covered by a cap and trade tax. However, we have a tax of US$ 5/tCO2 in Chile, and we are seeing changes following the adjustment of the tax threshold that currently affects facilities with equipment with more than 50 thermal MW as installed capacity. Based on this criterion, SQM paid approximately ThUS$ 360 in 2023, which corresponds to the emissions from the Coya Sur boiler. One potential risk is that all of our emissions pay this tax in the future.

SQM has set an internal price on carbon dioxide emissions of US$ 15 per ton emitted. The price is based on the analysis of emissions reduction alternatives through a marginal abatement cost curve, where the cost per abated unit for our operations was determined to be US $10-15 per ton. We also considered the current green tax system and future changes in criteria, moving from a technological one (boilers and turbines) to an emissions one (cut-off threshold of 25 kCO2e). Other international regulations such as the European Union’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), which taxes imports of various goods produced outside of the EU, including fertilizers, have also been included in the price.

Based on the terms of that agreement, we must purchase more electricity than the amount we estimate we will need for our operations. The excess is sold at marginal cost, which could represent a material loss for us.

answer.summary: The company explicitly discloses financial risks related to N2O emissions and energy production processes. It quantifies an internal carbon price of US$15 per ton of CO2 equivalent emissions (which includes N2O). Additionally, it states a current tax payment of ThUS$ 360 for emissions in 2023 and identifies a potential future financial risk if all emissions become subject to this tax. Furthermore, the company quantifies a potential "material loss" from purchasing excess electricity for its operations, directly addressing the financial risk of high energy production.
answer.notes: D-Rag evidence count: 3. Human verified: False

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company consider financial risks related to negative public perception of chemical-intensive agriculture

answer.classification_justification: [REFINED ANALYSIS] The company's documents discuss general sustainability commitments, community relations, and client/consumer preferences for sustainable products. While there are mentions of reputational risks related to poor community relationships and broader financial impacts from ethical programs, there is no explicit disclosure of financial implications, reputational risks, or threats to social license specifically associated with negative public or stakeholder perception of chemical-intensive agricultural practices. The closest mentions are about promoting sustainable farming products or general market demand for sustainable/organic products, which is not an acknowledgment of the specific negative perception risk as requested.
answer.summary: [REFINED ANALYSIS] The company's documents discuss general sustainability commitments, community relations, and client/consumer preferences for sustainable products. analysis_results.question_text: Does the company consider financial risks related to drinking water contamination from leaching of applied products?

answer.classification_justification: The company acknowledges several water-related risks. Its products are classified as "noxious to aquatic organisms," indicating an awareness of potential environmental harm to water bodies. The company also mentions a "sanctions process with the Superintendency of the Environment" related to water use by communities, which implies a direct financial consequence from environmental impact on water. Furthermore, significant environmental investments are made to "safeguard and preserve the environment around our operations and protect neighboring communities," implicitly covering risks like water contamination. However, the company does not provide specific financial valuations for the risk of drinking water contamination explicitly from leaching of applied products.

evidence.text: Our lithium products pose the following hazards to health and the environment according to the Globally Harmo nized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS): corrosive to the skin and eyes (Category 1b) or eye irritation (Category 2) and noxious to aquatic organisms (short-term hazard, Category 3).

We found ecosystem services on the eastern border of Salar de Atacama in the Vega de Carvajal and Agua de Quelana sectors, where communities report that they use water. There is currently a sanctions process with the Superintendency of the Environment.

We make important investments to safeguard and preserve the environment around our operations and protect neighboring communities. Over the last three years, we have made investments of ThUS$ 47,025 in 2023, ThUS$ 44,180 in 2022 and ThUS$ 31,127 in 2021. The investments in this area are mainly related to compliance with environmental commitments to monitor significant variables and implementation of mitigation and environmental management measures.
In 2023, no significant spills contaminating the soil or water (surface or underground) were reported at the company's operating facilities and production sites.

answer.summary: The company acknowledges several water-related risks. Its products are classified as "noxious to aquatic organisms," indicating an awareness of potential environmental harm to water bodies. The company also mentions a "sanctions process with the Superintendency of the Environment" related to water use by communities, which implies a direct financial consequence from environmental impact on water. Furthermore, significant environmental investments are made to "safeguard and preserve the environment around our operations and protect neighboring communities," implicitly covering risks like water contamination. However, the company does not provide specific financial valuations for the risk of drinking water contamination explicitly from leaching of applied products.
answer.notes: D-Rag evidence count: 4. Human verified: False

answer.classification_justification: The company explicitly states that it paid approximately ThUS$ 360 in 2023 due to a US$ 5/tCO2 tax in Chile. It also discusses an internal carbon price of US$ 15 per ton and mentions the potential financial risk if all emissions were subject to this tax in the future. Furthermore, it identifies an "Increase in the price of carbon (green tax)" as a climate-related risk.

evidence.text: It is worth mentioning that our emissions are not covered by a cap and trade tax. However, we have a tax of US$ 5/tCO2 in Chile, and we are seeing changes following the adjustment of the tax threshold that currently affects facilities with equipment with more than 50 thermal MW as installed capacity. Based on this criterion, SQM paid approximately ThUS$ 360 in 2023, which corresponds to the emissions from the Coya Sur boiler. One potential risk is that all of our emissions pay this tax in the future.

SQM has set an internal price on carbon dioxide emissions of US$ 15 per ton emitted. The price is based on the analysis of emissions reduction alternatives through a marginal abatement cost curve, where the cost per abated unit for our operations was determined to be US $10-15 per ton. We also considered the current green tax system and future changes in criteria, moving from a technological one (boilers and turbines) to an emissions one (cut-off threshold of 25 kCO2e). Other international regulations such as the European Union’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), which taxes imports of various goods produced outside of the EU, including fertilizers, have also been included in the price.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose financial risks or liabilities related to restoration of mining sites?

answer.classification_justification: The company discloses financial risks related to restoration of mining sites by stating that the cost value for restoration commitments is calculated at discounted present value. Furthermore, it mentions that disclosures to Sernageomin include the estimated cost to implement decommissioning plans for each mining site, and financial assurances are subject to approval, indicating a quantification of these liabilities.

evidence.source_url: https://intel.tracker-group.org/org_library/FactSet/Filings/05HZV9-E/CHEMICAL & MINING CO OF CHILE ... files (20-F) Annual report by foreign private issuers, for period end 31-Dec-22 (0000909037)_0001558370-23-006738-1.html
evidence.text: Sernageomin commitments for the restoration of the location of the production sites have been incorporated. This cost value is calculated at discounted present value, using flows associated with plans with an evaluation horizon that fluctuates between 8 and

evidence.source_url: https://intel.tracker-group.org/org_library/FactSet/Filings/05HZV9-E/CHEMICAL & MINING CO OF CHILE ... files (20-F) Annual report by foreign private issuers, for period end 31-Dec-22 (0000909037)_0001558370-23-006738-1.html
evidence.text: The main requirements of the law are related to disclosures to the Sernageomin regarding decommissioning plans for each mining site and its facilities, along with the estimated cost to implement such plans. The mining site closure plans are approved by Sernageomin and the corresponding financial assurances are subject to approval by the CMF.

answer.summary: The company discloses financial risks related to restoration of mining sites by stating that the cost value for restoration commitments is calculated at discounted present value. Furthermore, it mentions that disclosures to Sernageomin include the estimated cost to implement decommissioning plans for each mining site, and financial assurances are subject to approval, indicating a quantification of these liabilities.
answer.notes: D-Rag evidence count: 2. Human verified: False

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company consider financial risks related to class action lawsuits and legal challenges from health/environmental claims?

answer.classification_justification: The company explicitly discloses financial risks related to legal challenges, including environmental contingencies. Specifically, it mentions a lawsuit with a quantified amount of approximately MUS$227 and, under "Contingencias ambientales," details a regulatory process that could result in fines of up to MMUS$9, as well as the potential for temporary or permanent closure of facilities.

evidence.source_url: https://intel.tracker-group.org/org_library/FactSet/Filings/05HZV9-E/Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile SA (SQM-CL) - Annual Report for period end 31-Dec-2023 (Spanish) - PDF - 1 _ 4_20240228-61a61d1a-b2d6-ee11-abd8-12bc89a8f273_0_content.md
evidence.text: Trabajo de Antofagasta. La causa se encuentra en etapa de discusión. La cuantía del juicio es de aproximadamente MUS$227

evidence.source_url: https://intel.tracker-group.org/org_library/FactSet/Filings/05HZV9-E/Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile SA (SQM-CL) - Annual Report for period end 31-Dec-2023 (Spanish) - PDF - 1 _ 4_20240228-61a61d1a-b2d6-ee11-abd8-12bc89a8f273_0_content.md
evidence.text: Mediante resolución de fecha 28 de noviembre de 2016, rectificada mediante resolución de 23 de diciembre de 2016, la SMA formuló cargos en contra de SQM Salar por extracción de salmuera por sobre lo autorizado, afectación progresiva del estado de vitalidad de algarrobos, entrega de información incompleta, modificación de variables del plan de seguimiento, entre otras. SQM Salar presentó un programa de cumplimiento que fue aceptado por la SMA, aunque dejado sin efecto por el Tribunal Ambiental de Antofagasta en diciembre de 2019. En octubre de 2020, la SMA formuló nuevas observaciones al programa de cumplimiento, que fueron abordadas mediante la presentación de un programa de cumplimiento refundido, que incorpora mejoras en línea con la sentencia del Tribunal Ambiental de Antofagasta. Con fecha 29 de agosto de 2022, la SMA aprobó el programa de cumplimiento presentado por SQM Salar, el cual fue objeto de reclamación por parte del Consejo de Pueblos Atacameños ante el Tribunal Ambiental de Antofagasta. De aceptarse la reclamación del Consejo de Pueblos Atacameños contra la resolución de la SMA que aprobó programa de cumplimiento y éste fuere dejado sin efecto, podría retomarse el proceso sancionatorio en contra de SQM Salar. Dicho proceso podría concluir con la aplicación de multas, que podrían ser de hasta MMUS$ 9, cierre temporal o permanente de instalaciones y en el extremo, la revocación del respectivo permiso ambiental.

answer.summary: The company explicitly discloses financial risks related to legal challenges, including environmental contingencies. Specifically, it mentions a lawsuit with a quantified amount of approximately MUS$227 and, under "Contingencias ambientales," details a regulatory process that could result in fines of up to MMUS$9, as well as the potential for temporary or permanent closure of facilities.
answer.notes: D-Rag evidence count: 2. Human verified: False
